 VIET NAM NATIONAL HEALTH SUPPORT PROJECT 1. THE SECTOR A. Background Country Background 1.1 Since the late 1980s, Viet Nam has undergone a period of successful macroeconomic stabilization, structural reform, and adjustment to external shocks occasioned by the collapse of the Soviet Union. By 1992, the economy had fully recovered and growth climbed to 8.3 percent. The decade of the 1990s promises to mark Viet Nam's transition to sustained and rapid growth. While growth performance and future prospects are good, Viet Nam remains a very low-income country with a per capita GDP of less than US$200. Encouragement of broadly-based economic growth with policies that absorb and make productive use of labor will play an important role in reducing aggregate poverty in Viet Nam. However, certain groups--the more disadvantaged and those living in resource poor regions-- are likely to lag behind. The policy challenge for the 1990s therefore lies in taking advantage of Viet Nam's substantial growth potential while at the same time ensuring widespread participation in the benefits of development. 1.2 Broad-based economic growth will generate new and diverse income-earning activities for the poor in Viet Nam, but some will be unable to take full advantage of them because of illiteracy, lack of skills, ill-health and malnutrition. Ensuring access for the poor to basic social services--especially primary education, basic health care and family planning is doubly essential. Viet Nam has made impressive progress in providing widespread access to basic social services for a country with such a low income level. It has also developed an extensive system of social transfers and safety nets. Altogether public spending on these programs absorbs around one-third of the Government's discretionary current expenditure. But since the late 1980s the quality and quantity of social service provision has shown signs of deterioration. Secondary school enrollments have declined sharply and utilization of health services has also fallen. These developments have occurred in parallel with major changes in the provision and financing of social services as part of Viet Nam's ambitious program of structural reform. B. The Population, Health and Nutrition Sector 1.3 Past Achievements. Viet Nam's past record on health and fertility improvements has been impressive and matched by few low-income countries. For example, the infant mortality rate (IMIR) was roughly halved from about 156 per 1,000 live births in 1960 to around 83 in 1979 and was then approximately halved again during the next ten years. The total fertility rate, which was 5.1 children in 1979, fell by over 25% between 1979 and 1989. A number of factors jointly contributed to the health gains achieved by Viet Nam:
 -2- establishment of a vast network of primary health facilities throughout the country; implementation of a number of categorical health programs to deal with preventable health problems, such as malaria, diarrheal diseases, and immunizable diseases; and high rates of literacy, especially among women. A strong past political commitment to health resulted in a substantial allocation of resources to the sector. 1.4 Recent Declines. Beginning in the mid-1970s, however, a number of problems arose. Among these were the burden of improving the poor health infrastructure in the South after reunification, sharply diminished external assistance to the sector, acute macroeconomic instability and a deepening fiscal crisis in the mid-1980s. The political imperative traditionally accorded to the sector also began to ebb somewhat. Under these circumstances, inputs to the sector--drugs, equipment, medical supplies, maintenance--began declining. A well-functioning health service system has therefore been breaking down. At the same time, the sector has had to address a set of new challenges entailed by the transition to the market economy. 1.5 As a result of these developments past gains in health are threatened. Some health indictors have shown signs of reversal. There has been a major resurgence of malaria in the mountainous regions and areas bordering Cambodia. Malnutrition rates in Viet Nam are significantly higher than would be expected, rates higher than any other low-income country in South and Southeast Asia, except Bangladesh and possibly Myanmar. There is also evidence that the health gains of the past have been unevenly distributed. There are wide disparities in health, population and nutrition indicators across regions and provinces and between urban and rural areas. 2 Organization of the Health System 1.6 Central Level. Health services in Viet Nam are organized along a four-tiered system. At the apex is the Ministry of Health, which is the main authority in the health sector. It provides overall policy guidance and technical direction for the country. It is organized into 13 functional departments. In addition, it has specialized institutes which provide services of a tertiary nature and referral services in various specialties. These institutes include the National Institute of Hygiene and Epidemiology, the National Institute of Nutrition, and a number of other institutes responsible for research, training, and patient care in areas such as traditional medicine, pediatrics, tuberculosis, etc. In addition, there are a number of other ministries that provide parallel health services, such as the Ministry of Defense. Overall there are some 33 service-providing institutions at the central level under the MOH. It is widely recognized that there is a need to streamline the overall management of central health services. Viet Nam has achieved a density of service provision at all levels--including hospitals and health centers-- that far exceeds availability in most developing countries. For example, Viet Nam's ratio of commune health centers per million population is around 170, compared with 32 in Indonesia, 63 in China and 141 in Thailand. Similarly, Vietnam's hospital bed ratio of one per 389 persons compares favorably with one per 465 in China, 665 in Thailand and 1,743 in Indonesia. 2 Parts of this section draw from Viet Nam: Children and Women: A Situation Analysis, UNICEF, 1994.
 -3- 1.7 As in many other centrally planned economies, over the years Viet Nam has developed a number of self-contained vertical health programs, including that for malaria, tuberculosis (TB), acute respiratory infections (ARI) control and control of diarrheal diseases (CDD), with structures running down to the central district level. In general, the complex structure at the central level results in unclear and overlapping institutional mandates. As such, it is now proving inefficient in a market economy where coordination and integration would permit greater efficiency. 1.8 Provincial Level. The provincial level is administered by the Provincial Health Services. The Director of the Provincial Health Service oversees health activities in the province. There is also a Center for Preventative Medicine, which manages the cold chain for vaccine storage, provides support to the districts to perform preventative services and maintains a range of laboratory referral services. The provinces also run provincial hospitals and in some cases specialized hospitals. These general hospitals have facilities for care in specialties such as surgery, obstetrics/gynecology, internal medicine, etc. Altogether there are some 249 provincial general and specialist hospitals. Manpower at the provincial level totals approximately 35% of the nation's total. However, in practice most of the patients cared for at these hospitals reside in the general vicinity of the hospitals. The hospitals therefore serve many basic curative needs that for the most part could be effectively attended to at lower levels in the health care delivery system. 1.9 An additional function of provincial health services is provided by the secondary medical school. These schools train middle level health workers for their provinces--assistant physicians, nurses, midwives, and secondary pharmacists. 1.10 District Level. District Health Services have three components. The District Health Office has surveillance and program management responsibilities. The Preventative Medicine Service provides preventative services, including EPI, CDD, malaria control, Vitamin A deficiency control, and iodine deficiency control. It also provides support to the commune health centers to deliver these services. The District Hospital is staffed by general practitioners, obstetricians/gynecologists, pediatricians, opthamologists, dentists and in some cases ear, nose and throat specialists. The District Health Office and District Hospital have recently been combined into the District Health Center (DHC). 1.11 There are some 550 district hospitals in the country, one in each district. Most have excess bed capacity, with occupancy rates averaging only 50%. 1.12 The support that DHCs provide to lower level health services varies in quantity and quality. Since most health resources of the district reside in the DHCs, there is a need to improve the quality of services and focus the range of services at this level to improve the effectiveness of these facilities as a first referral facility. 1.13 Under the DHC is a hybrid facility, the Intercommunal Poly-clinic (ICP), that in theory is to serve some three to six communes. ICPs were intended to provide basic services at a higher level of sophistication than commune health centers (CHCs), the lowest level facilities. ICPs were to take referrals and give other back-up services and training to CHCs. In practice most have not fulfilled these roles and the Government is re-examining their future.
 -4- 1.14 Commune Level. Commune Health Centers (CHCs) are the unit of service delivery at the commune level. There is a wide network of CHCs and some 93% of communes have CHCs. The remaining communes, "white communes," are to be provided with CHCs over the next three years. CHCs employ some 23% of all health workers. In theory, each CHC is staffed by 3-5 CHC workers, comprised of at least one assistant doctor trained for three years and a nurse midwife trained for two years. In practice this is often not the case. The major reason for this stems from the collapse of the now largely defunct rural cooperatives that used to fund the operation of CHCs and, most importantly, staff salaries. This loss of revenue, combined with the pressures on public health expenditures since the late 1980s, have resulted in the deterioration of equipment and facilities, leading to facilities that are often run down and lacking in the most basic equipment and drugs. Many CHC workers are said to be working only a few hours a day in order to supplement their salaries through other means. In recognition of this dilemma, Government decided in 1994 to phase in the financing of CHC staff salaries by the state health budget over a three year period. 1.15 Each commune consists of hamlets and villages. A previously existing health worker, the brigade nurse, provided health care for local people prior to 1986. However, with the dismantling of production brigades, this household level outreach system largely disappeared. 1.16 Supervision. Given the tiered nature of the health system described above, supervision is meant to take place from the central to provincial level, from provincial to the district level, etc. Two major constraints largely prevent this. One is lack of resources-- transportation, travel allowances, etc. The other is lack of good training in proper supervision procedures. Most supervision does not examine the quality of care, facilities, record keeping etc., nor are workers advised, commended or reprimanded as appropriate. 1.17 Private Health Care. Doctors have been allowed to practice privately since 1989, either using public facilities after hours or, increasingly, out of their own homes or in small privately-owned clinics. An important group of private practitioners is retired health workers who have elected to take up private practice. While the extent of private practice is increasing, there are no reliable estimates of the numbers involved, especially for rural areas. This is compounded by the lack of clear official distinctions regarding what is considered private and what is public. The lack of adequate regulations governing private practice, which can ensure that medical standards are set and enforced, is of concern to the Government. It also inhibits those physicians who wish to expand their private practice but are unsure of what the rules are that might impact on this expansion. 1.18 The private sector is most visible in private pharmacies, whose numbers have increased dramatically since 1989. As noted in Section C below, private sales of drugs account for the bulk of household payments for medical care. Human Resource Constraints 1.19 While, as noted above, Viet Nam has high health worker per capita ratios relative to many other low-income countries, CHC workers constitute only about 23% of the total health work force. This percentage is less than optimal given that an overwhelming majority of the health problems are still infectious and parasitic diseases that could be tackled
 -5- at the CHC level. Because of their wider availability and better distribution, people are more likely to consult CHCs than any other level of public care. Thus, the need for ensuring that CHCs are staffed with well-trained and highly motivated staff. A particular need is in the area of maternal care, especially trained midwives. Most assistant physicians are male. Women are more likely to seek help from female health workers, especially for ante-natal examinations and delivery. Of the total workers in the sector, only about 14,000 are secondary or elementary midwives. These numbers are not adequate for the estimated 18.5 million Vietnamese women of childbearing age. 1.20 Training. Training is carried out in eight medical and pharmaceutical schools, plus 25 secondary schools. The eight medical schools produce some 2,000 graduates each year. About two-thirds of all doctors are trained at Hanoi Medical School, the oldest and most prestigious in the country. Quantity of training, at least at the physician level, is less of an issue than is quality and orientation. Community diagnosis and management of health services receive only minimal attention. Epidemiological approaches to addressing health problems in a community are needed in all health training programs. 1.21 Secondary medical schools, which train middle level health workers, are in need of improvements in both facilities and curriculum. The training is mainly didactic and for the most part does not incorporate modem client-centered, interactive methods, that are skills-based, problem-oriented (as opposed to focusing on topics or programs), locally- adapted and experience-tested. Information Needs 1.22 A major impediment to more rational planning for progress in the sector is the lack of reliable information on a range of issues. Most sources of data do not agree on the magnitude of health problems and status. Thus, there are often significant differences between data sources (e.g., MOH, census data, the Demographic and Health Survey) on such statistics as the IMR. There is usually no disaggregated data to indicate the size of problems for each disease within the general population statistics. In addition, there is a lack of accurate, population based information essential for policy decisions that need to be made in order to rapidly reorient the sector towards more market economy approaches. For example, Government lacks information on price, accessibility and quality of the available public and private medical care. It does not have reliable figures on health care utilization, particularly as this relates to socio-economic status. Without such information, it will be difficult to devise effective market oriented policies that can move the sector forward but that can also respond to the Government's traditional concern with equity. Current Health and Nutrition Status 1.23 Viet Nam has a relatively low average infant mortality rate (around 46 per 1,000 live births in 1991) and high average life expectancy (67). Under-five mortality is estimated to be about 81/1,000 live births (1991), reflecting the same disease conditions as infants. 1.24 Estimates of the maternal mortality rate (MiMiR) vary greatly across the country, averaging around 110 but rising as high as over 400 per 100,00 live births (1991). The conditions of delivery are a major determinant of the condition of maternal and the newborn's health. While reliable data on maternal health services are lacking, even the MOH data indicate a declining trend in the number of women delivering at health facilities. MOH considers that 35% of all maternal deaths are definitely preventable and 53% are possibly preventable. The avoidable factors most often include delay in treatment, delay in referral, delay in diagnosis, incorrect treatment or diagnosis and lack of transport, blood or drugs. 1.25 Viet Nam has embarked on a plan to achieve important primary health care goals in five areas by the year 2,000: 85% UCI coverage; polio eradication; neonatal tetanus elimination; reduction of measles morbidity by 90% and mortality by 95%; and 85% of all diarrhea episodes to receive oral rehydration therapy plus continued feeding. Substantial progress has been made in meeting each of these targets with neonatal tetanus elimination being the least successful in large part due to the lack of access to good maternal health care during pregnancy and delivery at CHCs. 1.26 Despite the progress cited above, relative to other developing countries, Viet Nam still resembles a typical low-income country in its disease profile, with preventable communicable diseases being the leading causes of mortality and morbidity, among adults and children. Malaria, followed by diarrhea and respiratory infections account for the majority of reported illnesses, while tuberculosis, malaria, diarrhea and acute respiratory infections (ARI) are the leading causes of mortality. 1.27 Malaria has had a resurgence in recent years with the number of deaths reaching 4,646 in 1991, the highest ever recorded. This worsening of the situation was primarily due to the under-financing of the National Malaria Control Program (NMCP) and was compounded by the changing epidemiological situation, serious problems of resistance to drugs and decline in general health services. Although mortality has been steadily reduced in the past two years, the risk of malaria continues to be a fundamental threat for about 35 million Vietnamese. 1.28 Tuberculosis is a less dramatic and visible disease in Viet Nam, though it is the second major public health problem following malaria. Annually, more than 50,000 new infectious cases occur, most of whom would die without proper treatment. Moreover, these patients infect annually more than one million Vietnamese citizens. With systematic treatment it is now not only possible to prevent the mortality caused by tuberculosis but also, and most importantly, to reduce transmission of the disease. This would result in fewer new cases per year, and such a gain in tuberculosis control is long-term. 1.29 HIV/AIDS is an increasing health concem in Viet Nam. As of November 1994, nearly 2,000 HIV infected persons had been reported since the first reported case in 1991. Altogether 22 provinces have reported HIV, with a concentration in provinces in the
 -7- South. Using different scenarios projected annual AIDS cases by the year 2,000 range from 4,000 to 11,000. Government established the National AIDS Committee (NAC) in 1990 with representation from ten ministries and four mass organizations. It is currently chaired by a Vice Prime Minister. Provincially there is replication of the NAC. UNDP has taken the lead in an effort to coordinate external assistance for the Government's efforts. Discussions are ongoing within the Government concerning an appropriate strategy for addressing the HIV/AIDS threat as well as how best to mobilize and coordinate external assistance. 1.30 As noted above, Viet Nam's child malnutrition rates are extremely high. Estimates of the prevalence of underheight for age (stunting) of children under five years are 49%; for underweight for height (wasting) 12%. The 1992-93 Viet Nam Standards Survey (VLSS) found that for children aged 1-2, when the impact of malnutrition has its most serious long-term consequences, one in ten children are wasted. Similarly, around three of every five Vietnamese children in that vulnerable age group are already stunted. Low birth weights, an outcome of intrauterine malnutrition, showed figures for 1990 and 1992 of 12% and 14%, respectively. While inconclusive, there is some evidence to suggest that these rates have been increasing. A 1993 nationwide MOH study of 3,062 children aged 8 to 12 from 30 schools in provinces throughout the country indicated that 16% have severe iodine deficiency disorders; 65% have mild or moderate disorders. Anemia linked to iron deficiency is a major problem. It is estimated that approximately half of all pregnant women are anemic. In rural areas, about half of young children are anemic. C. The Changing Health Sector--Sector Issues 1.31 Perhaps the greatest overall challenge facing the sector is how to respond to current rapid change. On the one hand it confronts the problem of a relatively recent and rapid demise in what was once a strong public health system. On the other is the challenge of how to take advantage of the opportunities that the new market economy context offers. 1.32 Decline in the Quality of Service. The developments described earlier have led to significant undermining of the past quality of health services. Medical and surgical equipment in district hospitals is sparse, antiquated and barely functional in many cases. A large proportion of commune health facilities have become dilapidated to the point of being unusable for want of equipment and medical supplies. A significant proportion of commune health centers have virtually no drugs or injections to dispense. Many commune level staff have had no retraining over the last decade or two, or at most only a few days. At the same time salaries of health personnel have declined in real terms leading to low morale and productivity. 1.33 Changing Patterns of Health Service Utilization. The symptoms of decline in health services are seen in a marked reduction in the utilization of health services. According to Ministry of Health (MOH) service statistics, the number of outpatient consultations has fallen in half since the late 1980s, from an annual rate of around 2.1 visits per capita in 1987 to 0.9 per capita in 1993. The inpatient admission rate also dropped sharply during this period, falling from about 105 per 1,000 persons in 1987 to 68 per 1,000 in 1990; since then inpatient utilization appears to have recovered but not to its former level. While the reliability of these reported trends is in some doubt, given weaknesses in the official reporting system and its
 -8- inability to capture utilization of private sector services, they certainly suggest a picture of reversal in Viet Nam's past gains in delivering health services. 1.34 The Challenges of Liberalization. In March and April of 1989, the Council of Ministers promulgated a series of measures designed to liberalize the health sector and mobilize new resources for the sector. These included: (a) introduction of user fees for health care; (b) legalization of private practice; and (c) sale of drugs on the open market as well as liberalization of the pharmaceutical industry. Each of these developments has presented its own challenges. 1.35 (a) User Fees. While eager to relieve the public budget from financing pressures for health care, the Government is concerned about the impact of private financing on the poor. Pricing regulations governing services rendered by public health facilities have recently been updated with clearer guidelines on protecting access to the poor. But the actual enforcement of these guidelines, their impact on revenues and access by the poor and their future adjustments are still serious concerns. 1.36 (b) Privatization. Drug retailing and private professional practice have been liberalized in order to harness private sector capacities. Private sector prices and quality are of concern to policy makers; there is a belief that the private sector can do more in health but policy makers are unsure how to best delineate public-private roles. That this is an important area of concern is demonstrated by the fact that expenditures by the private sector are by far the largest source of financing for health care. Estimates from the VLSS indicate that total household payments for medical care amounted to some 7,500 billion dong in 1993. Around 3,000 billion dong was spent on medical care contacts in which treatment was provided by the public sector--twice as much as the total amount of public subsidies for health. Only a small proportion of this amount was spent on payment of fees to public providers. Rather, most of it--2,800 billion dong--paid for drugs associated with, but often not provided as part of, treatment in public facilities; the state budget allocates only about 60 billion dong for drugs which are intended to be provided free of charge. Even more--4,300 billion dong--was spent on drugs by people who sought treatment from private providers or who resorted to self- medication. These figures suggest that drug utilization dominates health expenditure in Viet Nam, yet the public sector plays little direct role in providing or financing it. 1.37 Taking the public and private sectors together, it is clear that the public sector role in financing health care overall is small--the state budget paid for 16 percent of all health expenditures in 1993. Even for important public services, private payment dominates. Thus, public subsidies contribute only one-third of all spending associated with public hospitals, and less than 10 percent of all spending associated with utilization of commune health centers. These estimates show that the financing reforms introduced in 1989 have had a far-reaching effect, transforming the provision of health care into a largely private market. This transition presents both an opportunity and a threat to the poor. On the one hand, successful mobilization of private resources has enabled a much higher level of access to health care to be sustained than would have been possible with continued reliance on the severely constrained level of budgetary financing. On the other hand, the complementary role of the public sector remains thinly spread across all levels of curative and preventive health care, rather than narrowly targeted at priority areas of government involvement. This means that
 -9- the poor face lower quality and higher prices for basic health care at public facilities than they would if public resources were better targeted. 1.38 c) Pharmaceutical Sector. Prior to economic liberalization, the pharmaceutical sector was tightly controlled to serve the well defined needs of the socialized health service delivery system. However, with opening of the economy, there has been rapid growth in the number of entities importing and distributing drugs in both the public and private sector. As indicated in the sectoral analysis above, self-medication without medical consultation is now the norm. The previous system of oversight was not set up to handle the current massive influx of drugs and the situation is now largely out of the authorities' control. Given the potential detrimental health impacts of this situation, including already documented cases of increased drug resistance, there is an urgent need for the formulation and effective implementation of a national drug policy. SIDA is providing resources to support the Government's effort in this area. IDA must seek to ensure that its investments in the sector complement and further progress in this important endeavor. 4 1.39 Public Expenditures for Health. A notable feature of the fiscal adjustment of 1990-91 was that social sector spending was protected relative to other sectors. These increases offset the compression in overall government spending so that real expenditures per capita actually increased. However, the impact of public expenditures depends not only on how much is spent but also where it is spent--to what extent are these expenditures directed to those regions and provinces with large concentrations of poverty?--and how well it is spent-- to what extent are policies implemented so that the benefits accrue to the intended groups? 1.40 These considerations are particularly important when considering their impact on the poor. State budget expenditures for health are distributed between the central and local governments in line with their administrative functions. The central government budget for health subsidizes central and branch hospitals, which are administered by the Ministry of Health and other ministries respectively, together with preventive health care, medical training and research. Local government budgets subsidize lower levels of health care, with provincial governments responsible for provincial hospitals and the district level subsidizing district hospitals and, in some cases, commune health centers. Thus the central budget finances around one-quarter of the state budget for health, while the rest is spent by the local governments. Overall state budget expenditures on health in 1993 amounted to 1,442 billion dong, or some 20 thousand dong per capita--about half as much as the government spent on education. No official breakdowns of budgetary expenditure are available for local governments but estimates, based on analysis carried out for Viet Nam: Poverty Strategy and Assessment, suggest that almost all of this budget--90 percent--is spent on curative care in hospitals. Only a small amount, about 3 percent, is reported to be spent on preventive health care. An even smaller amount of the budget, 2 percent, is estimated to be spent on commune health centers. 1.41 Reaching the poor effectively means giving priority in allocating public resources to those health programs which the poor are more likely to use extensively. 4 These issues are elaborated in detail in Viet Nam: Poverty Strategy and Assessment, World Bank, 1995.
 -10- Targeting public expenditures efficiently requires that the poor also use a large fraction of the subsidized health programs. Analysis based on VLSS data indicates that, aggregating across all health sector programs, health subsidies are larger for the better off, reaching 28 thousand dong per capita for the richest quintile or more than double the amount spent on the poor, which averaged 11 thousand dong. D. Priority Actions for the Health Sector 1.44 The above description of the changing character of the sector suggests that there are number of actions that need to be taken if the quality of health care is to improve, particularly for the poorer segments of Vietnamese society: 1.45 (i) Revitalization of the Public Health Network. The revitalization and further extension of grass roots health coverage is essential if the Government is to assure a basic service outreach capacity for preventive, promotive and early treatment programs. Given current trends, without Government intervention the commune health centers will turn to fee for service arrangements in communes with some capacity to pay or wither away in communes that are unable to generate enough revenues. In any case, the basic infrastructure for delivering publicly funded programs like tuberculosis control, immunization, health education, family planning, nutritional supplementation, disease surveillance, epidemic control, and other community health services that are not amenable to fee for service arrangements could be greatly weakened. As noted in the World Development Report 1993: Investing in Health, these are among the most cost-effective interventions that governments with limited resources can support. For example, global estimates suggest that in low-income countries
 -11- short-course chemotherapy for tuberculosis costs US$3-5 per disability-adjusted life year (DALY) saved, making this one of the most cost-effective of all health interventions. Thus, there is a need to secure an essential infrastructure for delivering cost-effective, public health services with large collective benefits in which market mechanisms are known to fail. This is distinguished from health care that benefits primarily individuals for which markets work more effectively. 1.46 It is important to emphasize that the above effort should not be one that seeks to restore the commune health system to its former status as an all-purpose health service unit. CHCs as an integrated preventative, promotive, curative and supervisory facility may have been appropriate during the socialized system. However, conditions have greatly changed. Communes are no longer an organized production unit generating lots of collective resources. Moreover, there are changes in the demand for health care services. People are seeking higher quality care, or at least perceived higher quality care, and thus some are going to private practitioners, drugstores or directly to hospitals. Thus, CHCs need to emphasize as their primary role the provision of preventative, promotive and community health services that people may not be willing or able to pay for but that Government wants to assure. 1.47 (ii) Support for National Communicable Disease Control Programs. Within the general area of improving public health services, there is a particular need to focus scarce public resources on the control of malaria, tuberculosis and acute respiratory infections, which are leading causes of morbidity and mortality in the country. Together these diseases pose a heavy burden on the health of the population and a substantial drain on economic resources. Their control, because of its public goods nature, is necessarily in the public domain forming an essential part of public health activities. However, support for these national programs needs to be closely linked to the strengthening of CHCs, and DHCs, which are the critical links in the grass roots health system for achieving communicable disease control program success. 1.48 (iii) Strengthening Institutional Capacity for Policy Analysis. The analysis presented in section C above suggests that Viet Nam's rapid shift to a market economy has left the MOH and related Government agencies poorly-equipped to confront the urgent planning and policy challenges presented by the new market economy context. While there are a number of institutional issues to be addressed--future manpower training, reorganization of the public health service, etc.--, two would seem particularly urgent. The first is increased capacity to undertake public expenditure analysis. As noted in the sectoral analysis above, the Government wishes to substantially improve the way public funds for health are mobilized, allocated and used, so as to improve the overall quality and coverage of health services, reduce major public health problems and adequately meet the particular health needs of the poor. To achieve these aims, it must improve significantly its capacity for public investment planning in health in order to know where its resources for health come from, how they are allocated, how they are spent, and what outputs are produced. 1.49 The second major institutional challenge has to do with improving Government capacity to mobilize private financing for health. As also noted above, private expenditures make up the large bulk of total expenditures for health. Given this, the Government would like to mobilize private financing for health as well as private capacities for producing health

Strategy for Sector Development 1.51 The health sector in Viet Nam today is a blend of overlapping approaches to health policy, financing, management and delivery of services. These approaches stem from various sources, including socialist principles of equity and predominant state responsibility, a market-oriented view of a pluralist health system financed by user contributions, and internationally prevalent concepts for improving health care in developing countries such as Primary Health Care, Health For All, etc. The 1992 constitution marked a new direction, however, by stating that health is no longer guaranteed by the state but is still a basic right, reflecting the withdrawal of the state as the sole provider of health care. It commits the Government to certain basic health programs but also accepts alternative contributions to health care. 1.52 The current MOH formal health sector strategy was articulated in its 1992 "Strategy for Health for All by the Year 2000 and Strategic Health Plan for the Period 1990- 1995 in Vietnam". The strategy emphasizes nine health strategies for the pursuit of health for all, e.g., early prevention, comprehensive health care, etc. A number of National Programs have been developed to address the priority health problems, e.g., Strengthening the Primary Health Care Network, Program for Goiter Control, etc. Each of the national programs is centrally administered through a department of the Ministry of Health and some receive major funding from a donor, e.g., EPI from UNICEF. While these various programs represent a range of important approaches to basic health problems, many of them reflecting donor concerns, they do not collectively constitute a fully coherent and consistent approach to the problems of the sector. In part this reflects the conflict between an economically-driven requirement to reduce health expenditures and a political commitment to maintain or expand coverage. As a result, the priorities and support programs are sometimes only partly related to the question of financing and affordability. Sometimes this also leads to selective implementation of national programs in donor-funded areas only. The Ministry recognizes this lack of consistency in approaches and is seeking, through various mechanisms, to formulate a more analytically grounded and consistent overall health sector strategy. The strategy is currently being revised. Initial draft formulations of this strategy emphasize, among other things, the importance of diversifying the provision of health care by encouraging an increased role for the private sector, and reiterate the Government's strong commitment to achieving improvements in primary health care in the poorer regions of Viet Nam.

World Development Report 1993: Investing in Health argues that the inclusion of health care as part of a strategy for combating poverty justifies the public financing of a

It identifies five clusters of interventions that have been found to be highly cost-effective: prenatal and delivery care, family planning services, management of the sick child (with particular attention to diarrheal diseases, ARI, measles and malaria), treatment of tuberculosis and case management of sexually transmitted diseases. These particular interventions are at the core of the National Health Support Project. There is concern in the Government that regional inequalities could worsen in the near term in the course of anticipated overall economic growth. Thus, for the foreseeable future there is likely to be political support for directing resources to improving health care in the poorer provinces targeted by the project. The project aims to, among other things, strengthen local delivery systems, thus lessening the demands on higher level, more expensive care; make more transparent the MOH's resource allocation process so that resources increasingly go to provision of more cost-effective health services, and facilitate increased private financing of care, where appropriate, thus lessening the burden on public funding of health care. The macroeconomic work carried out under the proposed SAC II would address the issue of overall allocations for the sector. The work carried out at the sectoral level under the public expenditure component of the project would focus on the composition of these allocations, with particular attention to encouraging adequate investments in priority public health areas. These two concerns would

Sustaining the financing of drugs being sold in the public sector is not a problem. Drug selling in the public sector has many problems but sustained financing is not one of them. The issue of financial sustainability in the project involves the provision of certain drugs to certain people without charge. Controlling prevalent communicable diseases like malaria, TB and ARI as well as improving the basic health of the poor and of children require that adequate supply of drugs be made available to them at CHCs and DHCs without charge. Charging for these drugs could compromise the disease control and health improvement objectives of the project; on the other hand, not charging for these drugs may compromise the Government's ability to financially sustain the supply of these drugs over the long term. Thus the specific sustainability issue is: how can the Government sustain levels of financing in order to adequately supply those few drugs that need to be dispensed without charge for some purposes to some groups in the population so that its disease control and health improvement objectives can be met? 21. Based on projections of the malaria, TB and ARI programs, successful disease control efforts should reduce the extent of these disease problems over time. Thus in terms of financing of drugs for these programs, the requirements will eventually decline with progressive successes in disease control. 22. For other essential drugs for the poor, continued financing through Government revenues is being proposed in certain circumstances. Over the life of the project, public expenditures analysis and private sector mobilization under Component 3 will identify areas of current Government health activities where possible shifts from public financing to private financing are desirable. Resources thus freed up could then be used to sustain the financing of provision of essential drugs to the poor. This will be one of the specific objectives of Component 3, i.e. to identify sources of financing within the current and future pattern of public expenditures that may be more efficiently and even equitably replaced by private financing, and may then be used to sustain the project's financing of essential drugs to the poor.

 -70- Annex 7 VIET NAM National Health Support Project SUPPORT TO NATIONAL DISEASE CONTROL PROGRAMS INTRODUCTION The disease control component of the National Health Support Project would include program support for the National Malaria Control Program, National Tuberculosis Control Program and the Acute Respiratory Infections Program. The component would be implemented by the National Institute of Malariology, Parasitology and Entomology and by the National Institute of Tuberculosis and Respiratory Diseases through existing organizational channels. RATIONALE FOR SUPPORTING THESE PROGRAMS: * The three diseases have been selected as priority public health concerns by the Government because communicable and infectious diseases still pose an intolerable burden on the health of the population and a substantial drain on economic resources. The burden of disease falls disproportionately on the poor. Furthermore, their control is necessarily in the public domain forming an essential part of public health activities in the country. The three diseases are of particular high priority for the reasons detailed below. After years of effective control, malaria has had a resurgence in recent years, with the number of deaths reaching 4,646 in 1991, the highest number ever recorded. This worsening of the situation was primarily due to the under-financing of the National Malaria Control Program (NMCP) and was compounded by the changing epidemiological situation, serious problems of resistance to drugs and decline in general health services. Although mortality has been steadily reduced in the past two years, the risk of malaria continues to be a fundamental threat for about 35 million Vietnamese. Hence, protection from this risk of malaria for the population is imperative. * Tuberculosis is a less dramatic and visible disease in Viet Nam, though it is the second major public health problem following malaria. Annually, more than 50,000 new infectious cases occur, most of whom would die without proper treatment. Moreover, these patients infect annually more than one million Vietnamese citizens. With systematic treatment it is now not only possible to prevent the mortality caused by tuberculosis but also, and most importantly, to gradually reduce transmission of the disease. This would result in fewer new cases per year, and such a gain in tuberculosis control is long-term.
 -71- Annex 7 * Acute respiratory infections, particularly pneumonia, is the single most important killer of children under 5. While a program to control ARI is gradually being put in place, it presently reaches only half the children in need. DESCRIPTION OF THE SUB-COMPONENTS: Malaria Control sub-component: Objective: To reduce malaria mortality, morbidity and its social and economic impact in Viet Nam. To strengthen national and local capabilities for sustainable malaria control. Main Inputs: Insecticides, equipment, means of transport, training, IEC, program support. Indicators: Prevalence, mortality Main Outcomes: Coverage of all populations at high malaria risk by locally effective anti-vector measures, with emphasis on impregnated bednets; early diagnosis and treatment, improved program management including better epidemiological services, training, supervision, communication and program related applied field research. Benefits: Improved health status for the approximately 35 million people in Viet Nam at risk of malaria, in particular the 15 million exposed to yearly intense malaria transmission. Reduction of risk of unmanageable multiple drug resistance partially caused by the unregulated private pharmaceutical market. Increased socio-economic development opportunities in malarious areas. Implementation: National Institute of Malariology, Parasitology, and Entomology. Risks: There is a distinct risk that the attainment of a level of malaria control cannot be sustained after project termination. However, with the social and economic development in Viet Nam continuing at the current pace, such a scenario does not seem probable.
 -72- Annex 7 Tuberculosis Control sub-component: Objectives: To reduce tuberculosis incidence, mortality and morbidity including the psycho-social suffering caused by the disease. Indicators: Case-finding rate, cure rate, number of districts on short-course chemotherapy. Main Inputs: Drugs, equipment, transport, training and operations support. Main Outcomes: Reduction in tuberculosis incidence and mortality through attainment of a case finding rate of 70% of new infectious patients and cure of 85% of all patients enrolled in chemotherapy. Benefits: Reduced tuberculosis incidence in the general population. Cure of infected patients. Implementation: National Institute of Tuberculosis and Respiratory Diseases. Risks: A major risk is always insufficient compliance (patients under treatment dropping out) resulting in a very slow decrease of the incidence of tuberculosis in the general population. Benefits: Reduction in the mortality of ARI among children and improved health status in this group. Implementation: National Institute of Tuberculosis and Respiratory Diseases. The Population and Family Health Project (PFHP) will undertake a number of surveys and pilot efforts the results of which will be utilized in the implementation of the NHSP. Special Surveys and Studies to Address the Population and Family Health Needs of the Major Ethnic Minority Populations 2. With the exception of the Han, all of the major ethnic groups in Viet Nam are known to be demographically disadvantaged relative to the Kinh, with higher rates of both fertility and infant mortality. Little information exists, however, to understand the underlying reasons for their disadvantage. 3. The ten major ethnic minority populations will be over-sampled in the survey instruments and special studies mentioned above. Additional participatory studies, to be conducted among each of the ten major ethnic groups, will address their special population and family health needs. These assessments will be conducted using focus-group methodology among various sub-groups of the ethnic minority populations, including women of reproductive age, men of reproductive age, adolescents, grand-mothers, traditional birth attendants or others found to be important to decision-making processes in family health. 4. Topics to be addressed will include, but are not limited to, the following issues: (a) Beneficiary-needs assessments: These special studies will allow members of the ethnic minorities to communicate what population and family health needs they have that could reasonably be expected to be fulfilled during the project. (b) Knowledge, attitudes, and practice of family planning: Contradictory impressions exist regarding the acceptability of family planning services in Viet Nam. The Committee for Ethnic Minorities and Mountainous Areas (CEMMA) suggests that the
 -99- Annex 12 issue of family planning can be sensitive to certain ethnic groups since they do not want to adopt any practice that may jeopardize their cultural identity and preservation as a distinct ethnic group. In contrast, preliminary studies suggest that non-use may simply reflect lack of accessibility and poor method mix. (c) Care during pregnancy and delivery: In order to gain a fuller understanding of pregnancy- and delivery-care, special focus groups should be conducted with pregnant women, new mothers, traditional birth attendants, and relevant family members. Special Strategies for Ethnic Minorities 5. Findings of the Baseline Survey Exercise: Most ethnic groups are known from census and survey data to be poor, poorly-educated and isolated. It is therefore not surprising that their demographic profile is unfavorable. However the proximate determinants of their fertility and mortality levels and patterns have been little studied. A first step in the design of any special strategy is therefore a set of baseline surveys and participative baseline studies. A model exercise of this kind was conducted as part of PFHP project preparation in Dac Lac province 6. The major findings of the participative studies conducted in Dac Lac among a number of minority groups were as follows: (a) family planning, modern contraception and modern health care appear to be very acceptable to minority women, couples and communities (b) Government and health workers are not always in touch with community attitudes and interests in the health and family planning sectors and communications between program staff and communities need to be improved (c) there is considerable unsatisfied demand for temporary methods of contraception in many minority communities, particularly pills and injectables (d) health facilities in minority areas were often dilapidated and poorly equipped and supplied

Borrower's Contribution to Supervision (a) Annual work plans and budgets for the project would be prepared by each central MOH department and institute responsible for implementing specific project activities, and each participating province. The plans and budgets of the central departments/institutes would be reviewed by the appropriate technical and financial staff of the MOH and the Project Management (PMU). The plans and budgets of the provinces would be reviewed by the Project Director and PMU, and would be agreed upon between the PMU and the provinces. The PMU would consolidate the plans and budgets of the provinces and the departments and institutes into an overall annual project plan. (b) Semi-annual progress reports would be prepared by the PMU in a format to be agreed upon with IDA during the project launch mission. The reports would: (i) include a concise, narrative section describing major project achievements and problems encountered; and (ii) utilize a simple, tabular account to show details of actual accomplishments compared to agreed upon plans. The initial progress report would be due on December 31, 1996, with succeeding reports due on June 30 and December 31 of each year until project completion. The reports would constitute the basis for the semi-annual project performance reviews to be conducted by the Government and IDA. (c) Monitoring and reporting of implementation progress in accordance with the annual plans would be the responsibility of the PMU, with inputs from the relevant MOH departments/institutes and the provincial PMUs. The PMU would also be responsible for organizing annual workshops to review implementation progress with provinces, which would be timed to support the annual updating of operational plans and budgets (see below). (d) The PMU would be responsible for coordinating arrangements for supervision missions, and for providing information required by missions. Mission briefings upon arrival and wrap-up meetings would be presided over by the Project Director or a designated representative.

doc.abstracts: The National Health Support Project's overall objective is to improve the health status of the rural population of Viet Nam in the poorer areas of the country. Specifically, it will aim to: 1) provide high quality, reliable primary health care on a sustainable basis in fifteen of the poorer provinces; 2) reduce nationwide mortality and morbidity due to malaria, tuberculosis and acute respiratory infections, as well as the adverse socio-economic impacts associated with these diseases; and 3) strengthen the capacity of the ministry of health (MOH) in policy-formulation, planning and management. To achieve these objectives, the project consists of the following components: 1) service delivery in the areas of: (a) infectious and communicable diseases; (b) maternal and child health care; (c) family planning; (d) reproductive health services; and (e) other basic health care; 2) national program assistance for the Malaria, Tuberculosis and Acute Respiratory Infection Programs including provision of drugs, insecticides, transport, equipment and technical assistance; and 3) strengthening institutional health planning and management.
